title: The Censorship Party
summary: House Democrats use a hearing to target conservative media.. Imagine if a pair of Donald Trump's allies in Congress had sent a letter to cable company CEOs in 2017 blasting CNN and other progressive media outlets and asking why their content is still broadcast. Then imagine that a GOP-run committee in Congress staged a hearing on the societal menace of fake news and the need for government and business to rein in the hostile press.

title: AT&T Carves Out Pay-TV Business in Deal With TPG
summary: Private-equity giant to pay $1.8 billion for 30% interest in new DirecTV unit. AT&T Inc. agreed to sell a stake in its pay-TV unit to private-equity firm TPG and carve out the struggling business, pulling the telecom giant back from a costly wager on entertainment.

title: 'Pie in the Sky': Illusory Goodies Invented by a Labor Legend
summary: The songwriter and activist known as Joe Hill coined the phrase in a parody of a Salvation Army hymn. Linguist and lexicographer Ben Zimmer analyzes the origins of words in the news. Read previous columns here.

title: DoorDash Sees a Year of Slower Growth
summary: Delivery platform continues to gain market share from rivals GrubHub, Uber Eats. DoorDash Inc. prospered as the coronavirus pandemic caused families around the country to turn to the food-delivery company for at-home meals, taking business from rivals Grubhub Inc. and Uber Technologies Inc.

title: A Poison Pill for For-Profit Colleges
summary: The Democratic spending bill would put many out of business.. Colleges for years have justified charging exorbitant tuition by offering what they claim is an immersive education. But many closed their campuses during the pandemic and didn't discount tuition. Now Democrats plan to shower them with more money while punishing vocational schools.

title: Beyond Meat Signs Supply Deals With McDonald's, Yum
summary: Partnerships with fast-food giants set to take meat alternatives further into the dining mainstream. Beyond Meat Inc. said it struck deals to supply plant-based meat imitations to McDonald's , KFC and Pizza Hut, a victory in the company's effort to take meat alternatives into the American dining mainstream.

title: The Old New York Won't Come Back
summary: 'The pandemic changed everything,' we say. But we have yet to absorb fully everything that means.. New York

title: How Many Jobs Will the 'Stimulus' Kill?
summary: As many as eight million by our estimate, in part by gutting many of Clinton's successful welfare reforms.. President Biden's $1.9 trillion Covid-relief package is being sold as an effort to "get America back to work." It will do the opposite. We estimate that between five million and eight million fewer Americans will be employed over the next six months if the bill passes.

title: Biden and Allies Stoked Vaccine Fears
summary: Seeking to undermine Trump, Democrats, media and scientists made false and alarming claims.. President Biden has proposed an "unprecedented" information campaign to persuade people to get Covid-19 vaccinations. Why, when a pandemic has killed 500,000 Americans, does the public need to be convinced? In part because Mr. Biden and his allies spent 2020 stoking fear for political reasons.

title: Another Golf Great in a Car Crash
summary: Doctors said he might never walk again. Ben Hogan recovered, and so did his game.. It's a February morning, and the man with the most famous name in professional golf is behind the wheel of his car. He has long been regarded not only for his prodigious talent, but also for a distant, obsessed personality that has made many of his fellow pros say they don't really know him.

title: 'Just Asking' for Censorship
summary: Democrats expand their effort to shut down speech by targeting newsrooms.. The Democratic House majority this week put on a bold demonstration of its newest governing strategy-one it continues to perfect. Call it the "Just Asking" tactic.

title: 'The Snatch Racket' Review: Coppers & Kidnappers
summary: The Lindbergh baby was only the most high-proﬁle victim of an 'epidemic' of abductions in 1930s America.. Decades before actor Kevin McCarthy had his big-screen encounter with the pod people of Santa Mira, Calif., America suffered from an invasion of real-life body snatchers.

title: Prayer and Science Led Me to the Vaccine
summary: Like others in the black community, I was hesitant. Then I did my research.. Like many African-Americans, I had a great deal of trepidation about the Covid-19 vaccine. But last week my wife and I completed our course of vaccinations. My experience as a pastor and leader in the black community led me to believe it was the right thing to do.

title: U.S. Farmers are Planting More Row Crops Than Ever
summary: Planters wager that rallies in crop prices are just getting started. U.S. farmers are expected to plant a record amount of acres this year to take advantage of high agricultural prices after years of tough market conditions.

title: Costco to Raise Minimum Hourly Wage to $16
summary: Retailer tops Amazon and splits with Walmart, which is keeping starting pay at $11 an hour. Costco Wholesale Corp. will pay its U.S. workers at least $16 an hour starting next week, the company's chief executive told Congress on Thursday as lawmakers debate raising the federal minimum to $15 an hour.

title: Tesla Temporarily Halted U.S. Production Over Parts Shortage
summary: Elon Musk says production at car maker's U.S. plant resumed Wednesday after two-day shutdown. Tesla Inc. Chief Executive Elon Musk said the company paused activity at its lone U.S. car plant in Fremont, Calif., because of parts shortages but has restarted operations.

title: GameStop's Stock Posts Big Swings, Retail ETF Follows
summary: The fund known by ticker XRT is experiencing volatility again. The return of large-scale volatility to GameStop Corp. shares has dragged investors of a big retail exchange-traded fund along for the ride once again.

title: Many New Yorkers Want Barbecue, Just Make It Kosher
summary: Jews who adhere to dietary laws increasingly seek options beyond old-school favorites, such as delicatessen, that can be adapted to suit the rules. At Izzy Eidelman's newly opened barbecue restaurant on Manhattan's Upper West Side, fans of the classic American cuisine will find plenty of favorites, from Texas-style brisket to a smoky half-chicken.

title: Mr. Potato Head Isn't Going Away. Meet the New Potato Head Family.
summary: Hasbro is dropping the 'Mister' from the brand name and rolling out an inclusive family toy set, but will keep Mr. and Mrs. Potato Head characters. Mr. Potato Head, welcome to 2021.

title: German Regulator Steps Down, EY Changes Leadership Following Wirecard Scandal
summary: The once-high flying electronic payments company disclosed a $2 billion accounting hole. The Wirecard AG scandal is leading to more exits, with the head of Germany's accounting regulator stepping down and auditor Ernst & Young naming a new leadership team in the country.

title: GameStop, Other Meme Stocks Leap
summary: Videogame retailer's stock is still well below its intraday peak of $483 in late January. GameStop Corp. shares jumped for a second day Thursday as momentum surrounding the stock continued to build and derivatives activity heated up.

title: New York Health Commissioner Defends Nursing-Home Response
summary: Testimony comes after widespread scrutiny of decisions made at height of pandemic in state. New York Health Commissioner Howard Zucker on Thursday defended the state's response to the Covid-19 pandemic and decisions that affected nursing-home deaths during the height of the crisis.

title: Biden Calls Saudi Arabia's King Salman Amid Policy Review
summary: Discussion comes ahead of the release of a U.S. report on the killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi. President Biden spoke by phone Thursday with Saudi Arabia's King Salman, as the White House reviews U.S. policy toward the kingdom and the administration prepares to release an unclassified report on the role of Saudi officials in the 2018 killing of journalist Jamal Khashoggi.

title: Salesforce Posts Record Sales
summary: Business software provider lifts full-year revenue outlook. Salesforce.com Inc. posted record sales and lifted its outlook for the current year as the business software provider benefits from a broader embrace during the pandemic of software services among enterprise customers.

title: Biden Administration Reopens Facility for Migrant Children: What to Know
summary: Texas facility is intended to house increasing numbers of unaccompanied children arriving at southern border. The Biden administration reopened an emergency shelter in Carrizo Springs, Texas, on Monday to house unaccompanied immigrant children who seek asylum. The administration is seeing increasing numbers of children at the southern border, raising the prospect of a new humanitarian crisis.

title: Coinbase Files for Public Offering
summary: Crypto exchange tapping public markets amid bitcoin frenzy. Coinbase Global Inc. filed to go public with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Thursday, becoming the most prominent cryptocurrency-focused company to tap the public markets.

title: How to Deal With Job Loss Without Damage to Your Self-Esteem
summary: Most Popular News. Our careers fulfill a number of different functions in our lives, says David Blustein, a professor of counseling psychology at Boston College and author of "The Importance of Work in an Age of Uncertainty: The Eroding Work Experience in America." Work helps us satisfy our needs to achieve, earn an income, connect with others and feel like the authors of our own stories, he says. In Western cultures in particular, Dr. Blustein says, our jobs are often so integrated into our identities that it is common to feel as though we have lost some sense of self if we lose them. This can take a toll on your mental health. Unemployed Americans polled by Gallup in 2013 were more than twice as likely as those with full-time jobs to say they had been treated, or were being treated, for depression.

title: Stocks Fall Sharply, Led Lower by Tech Shares
summary: Dow falls about 1.8% after Wednesday's record. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped more than 550 points Thursday as a wave of selling that began in the technology sector took down swaths of the market.

title: NYPD's Top Uniformed Officer Leaves for City Hall
summary: Departure of NYPD Chief of Department Terence Monahan is the latest leadership change at the force. The New York Police Department's top uniformed officer is leaving the department after nearly four decades to take a job in City Hall, Mayor Bill de Blasio said Thursday.

title: Charlie Munger Renews Robinhood Criticism
summary: Online brokerage calls Munger's comments 'disappointing and elitist'. Legendary investor Charlie Munger continued a war of words Thursday with popular online brokerage Robinhood Markets Inc. over the way it and others have enabled and profited from the recent boom of individual investing.

title: Biden Trade Nominee Seeks Solution for Boeing-Airbus Dispute
summary: Katherine Tai at Senate confirmation hearing says she plans to accelerate talks with EU in bid to end counter-tariffs. WASHINGTON-President Biden's pick for U.S. Trade Representative said she would accelerate negotiations with the European Union to resolve a longstanding dispute over commercial-aircraft subsidies, citing the fight's negative impact across several industries.

title: House Passes Equality Act
summary: Bill to ban discrimination on basis of sexual orientation or gender identity spurred conservative opposition; fate in Senate uncertain. WASHINGTON-The House voted 224 to 206 Thursday on legislation to ban discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation or gender identity, an expansive effort that has spurred fierce opposition among conservatives over religious freedom and set off a new round of partisan fighting in Congress.

title: Do Democrats Trust Biden?
summary: After his blown calls on vaccines and the economy, some lawmakers don't even want to let him start wars.. Old Democratic friends have been warning President Joe Biden not to inflict his supersized stimulus plan on a growing economy in no need of rescue. Today these old hands from the Obama administration are enjoying vindication. Various reports show a robust recovery bearing no resemblance to the dismal scene described by the president. After Mr. Biden's faulty diagnosis and treatment plan for the economy, now it seems that some members of his party don't even want to trust him with nuclear weapons.

title: U.S. Seafood Suppliers Face Trouble for Lent
summary: Shipping turmoil, warehouse issues cost importers, restaurants during fish's most popular season; 'six months of shrimp rings'. Clogged ports and full freezers are snarling the flow of seafood to American dinner plates, boosting costs for fish suppliers and consumers.

title: Former U.S. Olympics Gymnastics Coach Dies by Suicide After Being Charged With Human Trafficking
summary: The state of Michigan confirmed the death, hours after announcing 24 charges against Geddert, a close ally of disgraced former team doctor Larry Nassar. Former U.S. Olympic gymnastics coach John Geddert died by suicide hours after he was charged Thursday in Michigan with 20 counts of human trafficking stemming from allegations that he profited from the forced labor of young gymnasts.

title: Fed Officials Upbeat on Outlook, Bond Yield Rise Not Source of Concern
summary: Fed officials attribute higher Treasury yields to expectations for an improving economy. Federal Reserve officials said Thursday they continue to see the U.S. economy in recovery mode, with several noting they aren't concerned about the recent rise in long-term bond yields and see no need to use monetary policy to push against it.

title: Red-Hot Stock Market Pushes More Companies to Go Public
summary: The number of firms listed on U.S. exchanges surges the most since the dot-com bubble, reversing a two-decade slump. The number of publicly traded companies is rising after a two-decade slump, a shift that highlights how businesses are clamoring to capitalize on the buoyant investor sentiment that has carried everything from stocks to bitcoin to record highs.

title: Digital Tools Aid Texas Plumbers in Wake of Winter Storm
summary: Initiatives launched by Ferguson and Home Depot during the pandemic are helping plumbers tackle another disaster. Plumbing suppliers in Texas are marshaling stopgap digital technology installed during the pandemic to meet a surge in demand for replacement pipes, valves and fittings damaged in last week's winter storm.

title: 'Simply Sondheim' and 'Women Without Men' Reviews: A Splendid Revue and a Most Stageworthy Revival
summary: Virginia's Signature Theatre pays tribute to the composer known for 'Company,' 'A Little Night Music' and 'Follies'; Mint Theater Company stages Irish playwright Hazel Ellis's 1938 drama.. Lovers of large-scale musicals have been feeling more than usually deprived by the Covid-19 pandemic. In theory, it shouldn't be impossible to webcast a musical, but it's technically very difficult-too many people, too much stuff going on-and the only one I've reviewed, the Irish Repertory Theatre's wonderful revival of "Meet Me in St. Louis," was a scaled-down version in which the actors "phoned in" their performances, taping them from their separate homes, after which they were edited together in the studio. So it is inspiring to report that Virginia's Signature Theatre, one of the top American regional theaters that specialize in musicals, is webcasting "Simply Sondheim," a fully-staged 33-song revue directed and choreographed by Matthew Gardiner and performed in the company's empty 275-seat theater by 12 singers and a 15-player pit orchestra. No, it's not "Sweeney Todd" on a Broadway-sized stage, but it is fabulously fine in its own right and comes across with irrepressible vitality on a small screen.

title: U.S. Treasury Yields Rise After Positive Jobs Data
summary: Move extends a recent climb in government bond yields. A wave of selling in U.S. government bonds intensified on Thursday, sending yields soaring after new data indicated a strengthening economic recovery and an auction of seven-year Treasurys met with tepid demand from investors.

title: Canada Slow to Improve Rail-Safety Oversight, Audit Warns
summary: Investigation follows fiery 2013 derailment of tanker cars in Quebec that killed 47 people. OTTAWA-Canadian authorities have moved slowly to improve oversight of rail safety, nearly eight years after a fiery crash involving a crude-carrying train killed 47 people and wiped out much of a small Quebec town's core, according to the country's top auditor.

title: Tanden's Confirmation Battle Puts Spotlight on Two Senate Centrists
summary: The fate of Neera Tanden's nomination to lead the budget office comes down to Republican Lisa Murkowski and Democrat Kyrsten Sinema. WASHINGTON-The fate of Neera Tanden's nomination to lead the Office of Management and Budget came down to two centrist senators after another Republican added his name to the list of lawmakers who oppose confirming her.

title: ByteDance Agrees to $92 Million Settlement With U.S. TikTok Teens
summary: Class-action lawsuit in Illinois stemmed from 21 separate complaints last year. ByteDance Ltd. has agreed to pay $92 million to settle a class-action lawsuit alleging it illegally collected some teenage TikTok users' data, according to court filings.

title: Chemical Change (Friday Crossword, February 26)
Boy Scouts Cease-Fire With Abuse Victims Committee at Risk
summary: An injunction that protects local Boy Scout councils from sex-abuse lawsuits is running out, and victims' lawyers may oppose extending it. A dispute between the Boy Scouts of America and childhood sex-abuse victims has put a cease-fire agreement at risk with the youth organization's survival strategy on the line.

title: The Long-Term Economic Costs of Lost Schooling
summary: Students who are falling behind now because of Covid restrictions may never catch up in their skills, job prospects and income. Imagine for a moment two objects in your hands. One is a piece of paper and the other a rubber band. If you squeeze your hands together hard and let go, the paper will remain crumpled, but the rubber band will return to its original shape.

title: Standing Up to the Amazon Thought Police
summary: I checked out Amazon, and the book "When Harry Became Sally" was indeed no longer listed. Ironically, however, Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was still available for purchase.. Your Feb. 23 editorial "Tech Censorship is Accelerating" was revelatory and cautionary. On that same day I checked out Amazon, and the book "When Harry Became Sally" was indeed no longer listed. Ironically, however, Adolf Hitler's "Mein Kampf" was still available for purchase. My two Romanian maternal uncles were taken away to concentration camps in Transnistria, and survived. They were forced to dig mass graves. My mother, now almost 102 years old, hid out through World War II, and was nearly killed several times. She remembers how it all began: riots in the streets, censorship, scapegoating and the dissolution of laws.

title: U.S. May Be Back, but the Europeans Aren't
summary: It isn't surprising that Germany and others are enjoying a thumb in America's eye.. Regarding William A. Galston's "'America Is Back,' but Europe Has Moved" (Politics & Ideas, Feb. 24) about Europeans' negative opinions about the U.S.: Can you blame them, since they draw their perceptions from locally distilled and commentated feeds of our media's reports portraying us as a dystopian society full of idiots and criminals (not all of them politicians)? Who would want to follow the lead of an evil, warmongering and energy-squandering/CO2-spewing nation founded and run by white, male racists that hasn't fully rejected the antiquated notions of capitalism, individual rights, personal responsibility, sacrifice for long-term gain and free enterprise?

title: Guaranteed Income Better Than Bigger CTC
summary: A guaranteed income is preferable to a UBI or CTC in that it goes only to those who need it.. Regarding Greg Ip's column "Capital Account: Child Tax Credit vs. Universal Basic Income" (U.S. News, Feb. 18): An option not discussed is guaranteed income, a payment targeted to the poor and middle class. It is preferable to a UBI or CTC in that it goes only to those who need it. And it addresses the fact that not all families include children, but all deserve financial stability.

title: Israel Has Many Baha'is but India Has Even More
summary: The largest number of people practicing the Baha'i faith live in India.. Regarding Reza Afshari's "A Slice of Persia in the Heart of Israel" (Houses of Worship, Feb. 19): Mr. Afshari might have mentioned that the largest number of people practicing the Baha'i faith live in India-nearly 2.2 million. The closest second is in Iran, with fewer than 400,000. The beautiful Lotus Temple, a Baha'i house of worship in New Delhi, attracts nearly four million visitors each year. The Baha'i religion, established by Baháʼu'lláh in 1840s, teaches that all major religions have the same goal to unify the world and ensure prosperity of all races in all nations. It is no surprise that secular India has such a large Baha'i community, freely practicing their faith. Their ideas of nonviolence, purity, respect for each other, righteousness, self-control and meditation resonate very well with the teachings of far more ancient Sanātana dharma, or the eternal way of life.

title: Covid Stimulus Should Help Smaller Businesses Survive
summary: Many small businesses have gone to great lengths just to keep their lights on during the last 12 months.. Andy Puzder argues that "'Stimulus' Does Little For Jobs" (op-ed, Feb. 22). His argument is that firms recognize fiscal aid is temporary and they aren't inclined to spend the stimulus money they receive. This might be true for large corporations-such as the one Mr. Puzder used to lead, but what about small firms? Mr. Puzder forgets to account for the small firms barely hanging on one year into the pandemic. Many small businesses have gone to great lengths to keep their lights on during the last 12 months. Imminent fiscal relief might be the difference between a small business making it to a period where most Americans are vaccinated and restrictions are lifted. Stimulus that helps small firms, especially those struggling, could be the difference in the length and size of the job market's recovery.

title: Where Were the Neighbors?
summary: Was there nothing there to see?. Regarding Bob Greene's "The Kindness of Strangers Probably Saved a Boy's Life" (op-ed, Feb. 13): This is a heartbreaking tragedy with a good outcome, but I must ask an inconvenient question. Up to this time, where were all the neighbors, teachers and peripheral family members? Was there nothing there to see? Someone famously said "it takes a village."

title: Twitter to Launch Subscription Service, Aims to Double Revenue by 2023
summary: Social-media company detailed its goals at an event for analysts, its first in several years. Twitter Inc. plans to introduce a subscription service for content creators and said it would explore tipping, as it looks to double its annual revenue and accelerate user growth over the next few years.

title: Homeland Security Refocuses Grants Toward Fighting Domestic Extremism
summary: State and local governments will have to spend at least 7.5% of their grant money to fight domestic extremism. WASHINGTON-The Department of Homeland Security for the first time is refocusing some of its grant programs toward fighting domestic violent extremism, a priority under the Biden administration.

title: Covid-19 Fraudsters Keep Targeting Jobless Claims. What Does It Mean for Workers and the Data?
summary: Fraudulent claims don't appear to be distorting long-term unemployment insurance trends. Waves of attempted fraud during the pandemic have plagued state unemployment benefits programs. We answer questions on what unemployment fraud is, how it is affecting the national jobless claims report and what states are doing to combat it.

title: 'Biggie: I Got a Story to Tell' Review: It All Started in Brooklyn
summary: A Netflix documentary looks back on the short life of the Notorious B.I.G., born Christopher Wallace, through interviews with his mother and rap collaborators. Head east on Fulton Street in Brooklyn, N.Y., where the neighborhood of Clinton Hill is about to ease into Bed-Stuy, and you cross St. James Place, at the point where it's been renamed Christopher "Notorious B.I.G." Wallace Way. The intersection's namesake is on view in a portrait that occupies one corner, the eyes hidden behind sunglasses, a baleful look balancing on his face. It's the perfect representation of a public persona.

title: 'The Father': Who Are You? Who Am I?
summary: Starring Anthony Hopkins and Olivia Colman, Florian Zeller's feature explores the mind of a man experiencing memory loss.. In one sense "The Father," opening in theaters, amounts to a chamber piece. It's a relatively small-scale production that centers on a widower father and his dutiful daughter. Eighty-year-old Anthony, played by Anthony Hopkins, lives alone in his quite comfortable London flat, though with ever more difficulty as his memory declines and his confusion grows. Anne, played by Olivia Colman, visits him as often as she can, though she's no substitute for any of the full-time caregivers he has tolerated briefly, then chased away. Yet the film looms large dramatically because its true chamber is Anthony's mind, a fantastical place where memories swirl, delusions dance, pleasures beckon, terrors arise unbidden and people both beloved and mistrusted keep splitting off into other identities. The two Anthonys, by contrast, coalesce. Actor merges with character in a performance that's astonishing and inspiring in equal measure.

title: 'Debris' Review: Unidentified Flying Objects
summary: Intelligence agents attempt to solve an extraterrestrial mystery in NBC's new sci-fi drama. It's a dangerous thing to become infatuated with the first episode of a series, because pilots can be like first dates: Everything is candy and flowers, but what follows can be years of domestic drudgery, boredom and an acrimonious divorce. Still, it's hard not to warm to NBC's ambitious "Debris," which may just sweep viewers off their feet.

title: 'The United States vs. Billie Holiday' Review: Singer in Their Sights
summary: In Lee Daniels's feature, Andra Day stars as the celebrated vocalist, who was pursued by the federal government as part of its war on drugs.. 'The United States vs. Billie Holiday," starring Andra Day and streaming on Hulu, is a muddled chronicle of the persecution visited on the peerless jazz vocalist in the 1940s by the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and its commissioner, Harry Anslinger. (He's played coarsely by Garrett Hedlund.)

title: Twitter Lets It Fly
summary: Social-media platform aimed high with an ambitious set of targets Thursday. Twitter is a destination for fact and for fluff. Both are often taken with equal weight.

title: Dead Chickens, Frozen Oranges Confront Farmers After Severe Cold
summary: The wintry blast in Texas and other southern U.S. states led to euthanized chicks, frostbitten cow udders and hundreds of millions of dollars in losses. Severe winter conditions across the U.S. south this month left hundreds of thousands of chickens dead and froze groves of fruit, pushing the episode's estimated cost to farmers and agriculture companies into the hundreds of millions of dollars, industry officials said.

title: World Wars Couldn't Stop Venice's Caffe Florian. Covid Did.
summary: Historic Caffè Florian, the city's most opulent coffeehouse and unofficial hub for Carnival, was a gleeful time warp until Covid temporarily closed it last year. For the Time Capsule series, we spotlight a cherished restaurant, hotel or landmark that's changed remarkably little over the years. This week, we visit Caffè Florian in Venice, Italy.

title: Chip Makers Applaud Biden's Catch-Up Effort but See No Quick Fix
summary: Industry executives expect U.S. push to address chip shortages will take years amid surging demand, complexity of supply chains. President Biden's pledge to fix the chip shortages hitting auto makers and others will take years to deliver, according to industry officials who are pressing the administration for long-desired support as demand for such processors continues to soar.

title: Unemployment Claims Fell Sharply Last Week
summary: Filings for initial jobless claims dropped to 730,000, the lowest weekly level since late November. The jobs market appears to be returning to growth, with new applications for unemployment benefits falling to the lowest level since November amid other signs hiring is picking up.

title: Petrobras CEO Says He Will Step Down as Brazil's President Moves in on Oil Giant
summary: Market-friendly Castello Branco's departure raises fears of Bolsonaro economic populism. SÃO PAULO-The market-friendly chief executive of Brazilian oil producer Petrobras said Thursday he would step down, paving the way for his replacement with an army general as President Jair Bolsonaro fights for greater control of the company.

title: Iron Curtains Are Older Than the Cold War
summary: Winston Churchill made the term famous, but ideological rivalries have driven geopolitics since Athens and Sparta. Historian Amanda Foreman searches the past for the origins of today's world. Read previous columns here.

title: Sen. Paul Presses Transgender Health Nominee About Minors
summary: Hearing for Biden nominee for assistant health secretary turns tense as she is pressed over her stance on gender dysphoria treatment for minors. A hearing for a transgender person nominated by President Biden for a top administration health position turned tense Thursday as she was pressed over her stance on gender dysphoria treatment for minors.

title: Paramount+ Hits a Divided Audience
summary: ViacomCBS stock had surged ahead of streaming event, sharply splitting Wall Street. As much as Wall Street has taken to cheering any and all streaming efforts, sometimes the celebration can be premature.

title: Recipes to Celebrate Black History Month
summary: From rib-eye steak with a nutty Nigerian-style spice rub to a comforting plate of beans and rice, these recipes are deeply rooted in the experiences of the chefs who created them. THESE INFLUENTIAL Black chefs shared their stories and recipes in The Wall Street Journal's Slow Food Fast column. Here they discuss what the recipes mean to them, their larger cultural and historical resonance, and how they reflect their individual approaches to cooking.

title: Amazon's Lack of Disclosure on SolarWinds Hack Angers Lawmakers
summary: Tech giant says it wasn't breached, but it is seen as having valuable data on the attack. As lawmakers and security researchers continue to unravel the SolarWinds hack, some are growing more frustrated with Amazon.com Inc., saying the cloud-computing giant should be more publicly forthcoming about its knowledge of the suspected Russian cyberattack.

title: For These Retirees, Short-Term Rental Bans Aren't Just a Perk-They're a Must
summary: Some senior homeowners are seeking out neighborhoods and communities that keep online platforms like Airbnb and Vrbo at bay. When Wes Swenson sold his data center company in 2017, he was able to buy the retirement homes of his dreams in Utah. He purchased a $1.5 million house in Woodland Hills and a $1.2 million house in St. George. Both homes are in resort-like communities that tourists love; the former for skiing and the latter for access to Zion National Park, hiking and golf. Both are also in cities where homeowners can make high fees from short-term renting their houses.

title: A St. George Sanctuary
summary: Wes Swenson sought out a home in community where short-term rentals are banned.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Number Puzzles (Saturday, February 27)
Deadly Unrest Roils Iranian City
summary: Clashes between protesters and security forces in impoverished minority region follow killing of fuel traders. Protesters in Iran's impoverished southeast clashed with security forces for a third consecutive day, in the latest challenge for a government facing public resentment over widespread economic hardship in the country.

title: Yellen Can't Save the Polar Bears
summary: What happens if financial regulators try to address the climate? Expect the usual corporate favoritism.. The House Financial Services Committee holds a hearing Thursday on "Climate Change and Social Responsibility: Helping Corporate Boards and Investors Make Decisions for a Sustainable World." This follows a flurry of Biden administration initiatives to thrust climate change to the forefront of financial regulation. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen has announced her department will create a "climate hub," complete with a "climate czar." As Ms. Yellen stated at her confirmation hearing, the goal is to ensure that financial regulators "seriously look at assessing the risk to the financial system from climate change." This plan will accomplish nothing to save the planet but will surely amount to a tax on borrowers and investors.

title: Biden's Stimulus and the 'Financialization' of Taxes
summary: How to pay for all the new spending? The president proposes heavier reliance on capital-gains levies.. A central Republican criticism of the $1.9 trillion Covid "stimulus" Democrats plan to ram through Capitol Hill is that taxes will have to rise eventually to pay back all the debt funding this spree. That's more controversial than it ought to be-Democrats and their intellectual enablers seem certain money grows on trees-but it also elides an interesting question: Which taxes?

title: The Power of the Wandering Mind
summary: Research shows that daydreaming and woolgathering are specialized mental functions with a unique pattern of brain waves. Psychologist Alison Gopnik explores new discoveries in the science of human nature. Read previous columns here.

title: TikTok's Feta Pasta Is a Thing. Everyone Is Doing It Wrong.
summary: The seemingly simple recipe, widely shared, exposed some culinary shortcomings; 'Canned tomatoes. Please no.'. The baked-feta pasta that went viral on TikTok and other social-media platforms this month has people all over the world obsessing over it, making a run on cheese and posting appetizing pictures of their creations. The dish is pitched as incredibly easy to make, with a gourmet look and taste.

title: Best Buy Tests Its Luck
summary: Retailer's decisive approach to operational changes will be challenged again this year. Best Buy is one nimble retailer. Is its latest turn too fast?

title: India, Pakistan Agree to Cease-Fire Along Their Disputed Border
summary: Surprise agreement followed a conversation between senior military officers of the two countries over a hotline. ISLAMABAD-Pakistan and India agreed to a cease-fire along their disputed border, long regarded as one of the most dangerous frontiers in the world.

title: History Drives Distrust in Covid-19 Vaccines for Black Americans in Tuskegee
summary: Resume Subscription. TUSKEGEE, Ala.-Black residents of this Southern town say the pain and distrust fomented by a decadeslong syphilis study here are inseparable from their personal deliberations over whether to take a Covid-19 vaccine.

title: TIAA Names JPMorgan's Thasunda Brown Duckett as CEO
summary: Duckett is a leading voice among bankers in the need to close the wealth gap between white and Black Americans. Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association of America named JPMorgan Chase & Co.'s Thasunda Brown Duckett as president and chief executive, tapping a powerful consumer banker and one of Wall Street's most-prominent Black executives.

title: Best Buy Workers Powered Through Pandemic. Then They Lost Their Jobs.
summary: Electronics retailer warns pandemic-fueled gains will end and tries to speed its digital transformation. That means new roles, fewer hours for some workers.. Best Buy Co. said sales surged in the holiday season as homebound consumers splurged on televisions and other electronics, but warned that its torrid growth would slow this year and said it has pushed forward plans to prepare the business for a more digital future.

title: Argentine Government Drags Feet on Deal With IMF
summary: Ruling Peronists want to wait until after October mid-term elections; Hope economic recovery can trim deficit. MEXICO CITY-Argentina's leftist government is unlikely to reach a deal with the International Monetary Fund to repay $44 billion in debt before the country's October midterm elections, extending the uncertainty for South America's second biggest economy, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: The California Home Bryan Cranston Built During 'Breaking Bad' Lists for $4.995 Million
summary: Resume Subscription. As he was portraying Walter White, celebrated as one of the most greedy and unrepentant bad guys ever created, actor Bryan Cranston was building a beach house inspired by his longtime instincts for environmental preservation.

title: Target Carves Out Space for Apple Products
summary: Partnership would double Apple footprint in select stores. Target Corp. is creating enclaves for Apple Inc. products at its retail stores that would double the space for the tech company's products in certain Target locations.

title: How Uniqlo Heattech Became This Writer's Secret Weapon in Winter
summary: Mary H.K. Choi, author of the forthcoming novel 'Yolk,' reflects on her co-dependent cold-weather relationship with the rayon-blend long-johns. PEER INTO MY apartment from the apartment across the street to catch me unaware, en dishabille, and you'll find me in Uniqlo Heattech. From the months of October to May, I am blotted out from head-to-toe in Japan's finest rayon/poly/acrylic long-johns, spidering from room to room like some middle-aged stagehand or deeply prosaic mime. Rising before the alarm, shucking off pajamas, counting out knee bends; toe touches, climbing into a sweatsuit, huddling into my house coat, breakfasting, attempting correspondences, shambling about my day and muttering to myself-all of this is done as a Heattech never-nude. The only time I am absent my protective sheath is for a desultory shower and the attendant ritual of observing an astonishing volume of emollient disappear into my body and face.

title: Pfizer, BioNTech Studying Third Covid-19 Vaccine Dose
summary: The companies are testing whether another shot would increase effectiveness against variant identified in South Africa and other strains. Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE have begun a study testing in people whether the companies' Covid-19 shot can provide protection against emerging strains of the coronavirus.

title: Claude Ganz, a Nazi-Era Refugee, Found a CEO's Perch in California
summary: Executive, who has died at 89, ran Dymo Industries and advised Bosnia on its economy. As a boy, Claude Ganz wondered where, if anywhere, he belonged. Born into a Jewish family in Germany in 1931, he escaped the Nazi regime with his immediate family and settled near Paris in the mid-1930s. When Nazi troops occupied Paris in 1940, the Ganz family retreated south and later were herded into a concentration camp at Gurs in southwestern France.

title: Can an Active Lifestyle Help Ward Off Alzheimer's?
summary: Research suggests that non-drug treatments based on mental and social stimulation can help older adults fight neurological degeneration. The shutdown of schools, libraries, gyms and extracurricular activities due to the Covid-19 pandemic has parents and teachers worried about the toll on children's learning and development. But children aren't the only ones at risk. Young people need enrichment to build cognitive capacity, while adults, especially older ones, need it to maintain cognitive capacity and prevent neurodegeneration. In particular, decades of research show that mental, physical and social stimulation is one of the potential ways to ward off Alzheimer's disease.

title: Facebook Fight Over Media Payments Shifts Focus to Europe
summary: As EU adopts a new copyright law, some call for stricter measures against big tech firms. BRUSSELS-Australia's fight with Facebook Inc. over media content is focusing attention on European efforts to force tech giants to pay more for news, as European politicians urge national governments to quickly enact new legislation that would strengthen the hand of news organizations in their battle with internet behemoths.

title: Yellen Urges Increased G-20 Support for Global Vaccination Efforts
summary: 'This is a moment made for action and for multilateralism'. WASHINGTON-Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen issued an urgent call for global cooperation to defeat the coronavirus pandemic and bolster the global economic recovery, in a letter to her international counterparts Thursday.

title: Widows Run for Congress After Husbands' Covid-19 Deaths
summary: Susan Wright and Julia Letlow compete in elections to fill two House seats. WASHINGTON-Widows replacing their late husbands once was a common path for women to enter Congress, but the practice dwindled over time. This year, the coronavirus pandemic might bring it back.

title: Herbalife CFO Looks to Change Investor Views After Years of Activist Pressure
summary: The nutrition company hopes to shift its shareholder base to include more long-term, international investors. Herbalife Nutrition Ltd. 's new finance chief is working to change investors' view of the business after years of activist pressure, which abated in January when Carl Icahn -once its largest shareholder-sold a large chunk of his stake and relinquished his board seats.

title: Durable-Goods Climbed 3.4% in January
summary: New orders posted ninth straight month of gains and the largest percentage increase since July 2020. Demand for long-lasting manufactured goods jumped in January, as the U.S. economic recovery gained momentum at the start of the year.

title: GameStop, Koss, AMC: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Stocks popular with Reddit users were soaring premarket. And you thought the GameStop frenzy was over. Not so fast. Here's what we're watching ahead of the bell on Thursday.

title: Some New Jersey Nursing Homes Will Resume Visitations
summary: Overall, the state has administered 1.76 million doses of the vaccine. Indoor visitations will soon be able to resume at some New Jersey nursing homes as Covid-19 cases continue to fall, public-health officials said.

title: China Lets Yuan Rise Steadily, Pressuring Exporters
summary: Currency has climbed 9% against U.S. dollar since June, forcing some companies hit by pandemic-related expenses to consider raising cost of goods. HONG KONG-China's currency has continued to climb in value this year on the back of a strong economic recovery, and Beijing doesn't appear to be in a hurry to weaken it despite the pressure it is putting on exporters.

title: Washington, D.C., Police Fight a Rise in Carjackings and Blame Covid-19
summary: Nation's capital, other cities report sharp increases in carjackings in 2020. During the pandemic, police officers in Washington, D.C., started noticing a rise in a crime that alarmed them: teenagers forcibly stealing occupied cars and often going for joy rides.

title: Facebook Ad Campaign Promotes Personalized Advertising
summary: The social-media giant calls targeted ads good because they help small businesses find consumers. Facebook Inc. will promote the value of targeted ads to businesses and consumers in a new ad campaign in digital media, radio and TV programming including National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball games and Sunday's Golden Globe Awards.

title: The NBA's Top Shooter Is Named Curry. No, Not That One.
summary: Philadelphia 76ers guard Seth Curry has quietly become the most accurate 3-point shooter in the league-and his own family.. Seth Curry was still in high school when a mesmerized coach watched him launch 3-pointers from several feet behind the line and felt a sensation that is now familiar to lots of people around the world: a Curry shoots a basketball and everybody in the gym thinks it's going in.

title: Was 'Punky Brewster''s Soleil Moon Frye the Original Influencer?
summary: In a new Hulu documentary 'kid 90,' the child actor and current star of the new 'Punky' reboot, who always had a video camera in hand as a teen, reveals her Hollywood coming-of-age story in the '90s.. Imagine a world with no TikTok, no Instagram, no YouTube, no Twitter, no Facebook. Now imagine that someone even more famous than today's selfie sensations like Addison Rae, Charli D'Amelio and Emma Chamberlain took about as many photos, videos, tapes and notes as they do. And then, instead of posting a single pic, she locked it all up for more than two decades. What you would have is the unfiltered life of actor Soleil Moon Frye, who grew up in front of Americans during the '80s as Punky Brewster, her pigtailed on-screen alter ego.

title: New Mail Trucks Are Finally Coming, but Don't Expect All Electric Vehicles
summary: Postmaster general says just 10% of new fleet will be EVs because it would cost $3 billion or more to go all electric. The U.S. Postal Service is finally retiring its aging mail trucks. It unveiled plans this week for a new delivery van with a host of improvements such as a bigger windshield, a collision-avoidance system and air conditioning.

title: Eve Hewson on Catfishing Strangers and Her New Starring Roles
summary: "Intense emotions come quite easily to me," says the actor-and daughter of Bono-who stars in this month's 'Behind Her Eyes' on Netflix and 'The Luminaries' on Starz. One thing Eve Hewson has done to ease pandemic boredom is create an online dating profile under a fake name. "I've been catfishing people," says the 29-year-old actor, laughing, "which has been a really fun hobby of mine for the past few months. I've been breadcrumbing. Have you heard this term?" (Breadcrumbing is when someone drops hints and encouragement implying a desire to meet with no plans to follow through.) Earlier in the pandemic, Hewson was quarantining in Dublin with her family, including her dad, U2 frontman Paul David Hewson, aka Bono, and mom, activist and businesswoman Ali Hewson. Now she's back on her own, renting a place in London. Catfishing aside, she jokes that all the downtime isn't so bad: "Actors are usually pretty good at being unemployed and sitting around doing nothing." Wearing a black leather jacket over a black turtleneck, she's warm and animated over Zoom.

title: Budweiser Brewer Faces an Ill-Timed Hangover
summary: Major investors in the world's biggest beer maker will soon have the option to sell their stakes when five-year lockups expires. Budweiser's owner could experience a fresh headache later this year, completely unrelated to the bars closed because of Covid-19.

title: Tiger Woods and the Long Way Back
summary: A car accident in California has golf fans pondering a legend's future, on the course and off. Golf can wait. In those early, gray moments Tuesday, when we didn't know much about the accident involving Tiger Woods-when all we had was some harrowing overhead footage of a crumpled SUV off the side of a winding Southern California road-it was possible to really let your mind wander and worry. Now we know more: Woods is hurt, with broken bones in his right leg and foot, and he's got a rod inserted after surgery, but overall, the news is good, very good, considering how it looked at first.

title: Lessons From the U.K. About a More-Contagious Covid-19 Variant
summary: Strain first detected in Britain last year has been found in more than 70 countries, including the U.S.. LONDON-The U.K. has become a testing ground for how a more-contagious and possibly deadlier coronavirus variant spreads through communities, displacing its less-transmissible ancestors and complicating vaccine rollouts and the lifting of lockdowns.

title: Vanguard Charts a Narrow Path in China, Staking Its Future on a Fledgling Venture
summary: The asset manager is betting that its partnership with China's Ant will give it some reach over the roughly one billion users of its Alipay. Wall Street has long cultivated China's biggest investment institutions to make inroads there. Vanguard Group is betting more singularly on the Chinese consumer.

title: Hard Seltzers Help Bud Brewer Regain Some Sparkle
summary: Beer giant AB InBev says alcoholic sparkling waters are helping offset weaker sales of Budweiser. Americans drinking more hard seltzer through the pandemic helped beer giant Anheuser-Busch InBev SA partly offset a continuing slump in sales of Budweiser and Bud Light.

title: 'Fortnite' Creator, Apple Fight Reels in More Tech Players
summary: Computer-game distributor Valve is the latest to be pressured into playing a role in a legal battle over app-store fees; 'it's not just you'. "Fortnite" creator Epic Games Inc.'s battle to paint Apple Inc. as a harmful monopoly is drawing more technology companies into the fray, as each side seeks to bolster its case.

title: Restaurant Stocks Are Overfed
summary: Reopening will be a blessing for U.S. restaurants, but not necessarily for restaurant stock prices. The end of the Covid-19 emergency will be a godsend for the U.S. restaurant industry. But in the near term, it might not be as good for restaurant shareholders as one might expect.

title: What Biden's Minimum-Wage Plan Means for Restaurant Workers
summary: Employers say eliminating $2.13-an-hour subminimum wage for workers receiving tips could cost jobs and raise prices; plan's advocates say it would provide consistent income. How restaurants pay workers would be upended by President Biden's proposal to raise the minimum wage.

title: Facebook, WhatsApp and Twitter Face New Rules in India
summary: Guidelines require companies to resolve user complaints quickly, among other measures. India is establishing new rules to govern internet firms like Facebook Inc., WhatsApp and Twitter Inc., a fresh challenge for the American giants in a huge market that is key to their global expansion.

title: Geely and Volvo Decide to Remain Friends With Benefits
summary: The auto makers have decided they can work better together as separate companies, a year after announcing a planned merger. Chinese car maker Geely has called off a deal to create the country's first truly global auto firm. It wants the benefits of the merger without doing one-the idea of integration without a sale presents certain advantages, but it also looks like an attempt to satisfy fussy shareholders. It remains to be seen if the path of least resistance is actually the best one.

title: Global Trade Roars Back From Depths of Pandemic
summary: Asian countries have seized market share that they are expected to keep. Global trade has rebounded from its collapse in the early stages of the pandemic, with China and other Asian manufacturing countries grabbing a bigger slice of exports of everything from masks to bikes-market share they are expected to keep after the public-health crisis fades.

title: Nvidia's Story Has Gotten Complicated
summary: Strong results were offset by worries about chip-production constraints and growing opposition to the Arm deal. Nvidia was truly in some uncharted territory with its fiscal fourth-quarter results Wednesday, in that the chip maker is facing concerns that even great numbers alone won't soothe.

title: Rich Countries Borrowed $18 Trillion in 2020. Few Seem Worried About Them Paying It Off.
summary: Developed-world governments sold bonds in record volumes in the first year of the coronavirus pandemic, but their borrowing costs fell. Rich countries' governments borrowed $18 trillion from bond markets in 2020-more than ever before-but their borrowing costs hit a record low, due to a big rise in bond purchases by central banks, as well as a lack of concern about public debt levels among private investors.

title: Bank Stocks Are Enjoying the Rate Party, Maybe a Little Too Much
summary: Higher Treasury yields create opportunities to pick up interest income, but benefit for shares may be limited without more loan demand. The move in Treasurys has been greeted like an all-you-can eat buffet by bank investors starved for yield. But they might not want to gorge themselves all at once.

title: Squeezed by China, Australian Farmers Cultivate New Markets
summary: Resume Subscription. SYDNEY-Alan Sattler had been in his tractor for three hours one morning last May, sowing hundreds of kilograms of barley seeds in Western Australia's arid wheat belt, when he received a text from his grain broker. China, his biggest market, was placing a punitive tariff on Australian barley.

title: Rare Bond-Market Inversion Signals Short-Lived Boost to Inflation
summary: Markets appear to price in a spike of inflation in the medium term that ebbs later on. Markets are signaling that inflation is coming and investors are getting ready. Treasury yields are rising and stock-market investors are starting to shift from high-growth tech companies toward companies like airlines that will benefit from an economic rebound.

title: GameStop Shares Soar in Last Hour of Trading
summary: Stock is still well below its intraday peak of $483 in late January. GameStop Corp. shares skyrocketed in the final hour of trading Wednesday, finishing the day with a rally reminiscent of last month's blockbuster gains.

title: Autonomous Trucking Startup TuSimple Plans to Go Public in March
summary: Company backed by Chinese, U.S. investors has filed confidential IPO papers. Autonomous trucking company TuSimple Inc., which gained momentum with hundreds of millions of dollars in financing from Chinese investors and U.S. freight-hauling companies, has filed paperwork to go public and plans to join the U.S. stock market as early as next month, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Ad Campaigns Aim to Counter Covid-19 Vaccine Hesitancy
summary: The work was informed by research showing nuanced concerns regarding the Covid vaccine, Ad Council and COVID Collaborative say. The Ad Council and COVID Collaborative are rolling out coordinated ad campaigns from multiple brands as part of a broad effort to combat hesitancy among some people to take Covid-19 vaccines.

title: Biden Rescinds Trump Immigration Restrictions
summary: Trump administration had banned most forms of legal immigration last year, citing high unemployment caused by pandemic. WASHINGTON-President Biden on Wednesday revoked most immigration restrictions that former President Donald Trump imposed last year in response to the Covid-19 pandemic.

title: Amazon Faces Questions Over Removal of Book by Conservative Author
summary: Republican senators send letter to Jeff Bezos in which they say the company's move signals to conservative Americans that their views aren't welcome. A group of Republican senators is asking Amazon.com Inc. to explain why it recently removed a book about transgender issues that had been on sale on the platform for about three years.

title: WeWork Co-Founder to Get Extra $50 Million
summary: Deal would set Mr. Neumann apart from other WeWork shareholders. WeWork co-founder and former Chief Executive Adam Neumann is set to reap an extra $50 million windfall and other benefits as part of an agreement that would settle a bitter dispute he and other early investors in the shared-office-space provider have waged with SoftBank Group Corp., according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Boeing-FAA Ties Still Flawed After 737 MAX Reforms
summary: Government review says Federal Aviation Administration needs to further strengthen oversight of aircraft safety. U.S. aviation regulators need to strengthen their oversight of aircraft safety even after reforms undertaken in the wake of the two Boeing Co. 737 MAX crashes that claimed 346 lives, a government report has concluded.

title: SEC Opens Review of Corporate Climate Change Disclosures
summary: The regulator's previous guidance on climate change was issued more than a decade ago. The Securities and Exchange Commission on Wednesday said it would review how companies are disclosing the risks they face from climate change, as the agency looks to refresh its more than decade-old guidance on the issue.

title: GameStop CFO Was Forced Out as Activist Investor Pushes New Strategy
summary: Chewy co-founder Ryan Cohen is seeking a digital transformation of the videogame retailer. GameStop Corp.'s finance chief was forced out of his role as activist investor Ryan Cohen pushes for a digital transformation of the ailing videogame retailer, people familiar with the matter said.

title: Icon to Buy Clinical-Trial Rival PRA in $12 Billion Deal
summary: Tie-up would expand role of technology in clinical trials and drug development. Clinical-trial operator Icon PLC said it would acquire rival PRA Health Sciences Inc. for $12 billion, creating a powerhouse provider of services to pharmaceutical companies that are farming out more work to contractors.

title: ViacomCBS Shortens Theatrical Window for Paramount+
summary: Company to offer some top Paramount movies on new subscription platform within 30 to 45 days of their theatrical release. ViacomCBS Inc. is planning to put some of the biggest movies from its Paramount film studio on its Paramount+ streaming service within two months of their theatrical release, Chief Executive Officer Bob Bakish told investors Wednesday.

title: Markets Suggest the Economy Is Booming But the Recovery Has a Long Way to Go
summary: A rally in everything from stocks to oil shows investors believe growth is coming. Markets are signaling that an economy that plunged into its deepest recession in decades just a year ago is ready to roar.

title: Moderna Says New Variant Vaccine Is Ready for Human Testing
summary: Biotech delivers first batch of doses of newly designed shot to NIH for study that could start within weeks. Moderna Inc. said it has made the initial batch of doses of a new Covid-19 vaccine designed to better protect people against a new strain of the coronavirus that has shown some resistance to the company's original vaccine.

title: Manhattan Donors Pour Cash Into New York City Mayoral Race
summary: A few ZIP codes accounted for a large amount of high-dollar donations to the candidate field. Candidates vying to be the next mayor of New York City have received millions of dollars from mostly local donors, including a concentration of large contributions coming from a few parts of Manhattan, according to city Campaign Finance Board records.

title: Facebook, Google Face 'Strong Pipeline' of Privacy Rulings in Europe
summary: Key privacy regulator for European Union expects to boost number of big decisions this year involving tech companies. The privacy regulator overseeing Facebook Inc., Alphabet Inc.'s Google and Apple Inc. in the European Union expects to boost its tally of big tech decisions this year-and rejects complaints that its enforcement has been too slow.

title: Biden Announces Three Nominees for Postal Service Board
summary: President said his nominees would ensure the agency 'can effectively and efficiently serve all communities in our country'. WASHINGTON-President Biden announced three nominees to the U.S. Postal Service's Board of Governors, saying they would make sure the agency "can effectively and efficiently serve all communities in our country."
